article_metadata.description: Houstonians discovered a major flaw recently when they began comparing plans and discovered that no insurer is offering an individual Preferred Provider Organization option, whether on or off the federal marketplace.  Insurance companies spend most of their time calculating how much customers are willing to pay, how many of those people will need care and comparing that with how much doctors will charge.  Doctors and hospitals find themselves caught between patients wanting the best, and oftentimes most expensive, care and insurance companies trying to keep costs low.  Desperate patients want to use these facilities because they offer cutting-edge treatment, but these institutions also charge much more to cover research and teaching costs.  Insurance companies have been dropping M.D. Anderson and other teaching hospitals from their networks because they don't want to pay the premium when other specialists are willing to offer similar treatments for less.  The real fix is to require insurance companies to offer more robust networks, force doctors to explain their prices and educate consumers on how much health care really costs.  There are many problems with Obamacare, with some creating unintended consequences with prescription drugs and insurance company incentives, while other s are merely technical.
article_metadata.author.name: By Chris Tomlinson
